Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computational Intelligence Methods for Dynamic Stochastic Optimization of Smart Grid Operation with High Penetration of Renewable Energy

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop advanced computational intelligence methods to monitor, optimize and control large or so-called wide areas of a power network that will include solar farms (SFs) and wind farms (WFs), and controllable network transformers (CNTs), in order to ensure optimum usage of all these resources both during slow changing semi-steady state conditions, as well as during transient conditions. The research will be carried out in off-line simulations and then implemented on a real-time simulator.

Intellectual merit
The behavior of renewable energy sources is uncertain and variable, and it is difficult for static optimization methods to optimize uncertain non-stationary distributed energy resources in a smart grid for maximum utilization. A novel ACD controller is proposed for the development of a real- time dynamic stochastic optimization smart grid engine. Advanced intelligent methods such as the biologically inspired artificial neural network and smart devices (CNTs) provide better identification and control capabilities for implementation of optimal power flows.

Broader Impacts
Economically operated reliable and secure power systems that can accommodate high penetration of renewable energy are of national interest. Being able to route power through underutilized lines will have major economic and environmental benefits due to avoiding the need for new lines. This project will have several dissemination channels, including software, websites, new contents added to existing courses, special sessions and tutorials at conferences, and journal publications.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The demand for electricity continues to grow and together with fuel shortages and environmental pollution issues,calls for increased use of environment-friendly renewable but intermittent energy sources such as wind and solar. With the increasing penetration of intermittent renewable energy, power systems encounter more and more uncertainty and variability and over loading of certain lines. A power system is a multi-input multi-output (MIMO), nonlinear, and non-stationary complex dynamic plant, even without wind and solar farms. Due to the stochastic nature of wind and solar energies, when they are integrated into the existing power system, the system becomes even more complex. How to reliably and efficiently operate and control a power system in such an environment is challenging question and was addressed in this project. Neurocontrol offers nonlinear optimal control without the need for any mathematical model of the system, which is particularly useful for the nonlinear, stochastic power systems with uncertainty. The investigators have shown that feedforward, recurrent and echo state neural networks are able to identify and optimally control nonlinear non-stationary systems; this has been demonstrated on small scale power networks consisting of 12 buses, 3 generators and 2 FACTS devices, represented by a few dozen state variables. However, practical power networks typically consist of thousands of buses and hundreds of generators and control points with several thousands of sensors scattered throughout large geographic areas. These traditional neural network architectures start to break down as one tries to scale up to thousands of variables. This problem was addressed with cellular neura/computational networks, adaptive critic designs for dynamic optimization and new brain-inspired neural network architectures that have brain-like scalable performance and are able to make adaptive optimal decisions over time which will be needed for successful smart grid operation.

Several graduate and undergraduate students were trained on this project at Clemson University and Georgia Institute of Technology. The findings of this project have disseminated in over 70 refereed publications. Numerous tutorials, keynotes, panels and invited talks have been presented by the PIs nationally and internationally.

 


Last Modified: 04/25/2019
Modified by: Ganesh K Venayagamoorthy
